boardgame.description: Shogun is based on the Wallenstein (first edition) game system. The game is set in the Sengoku period (approx 1467-1573) which ends with the inception of the well-known Tokugawa Shogunate._T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;The game is an international edition with language-independent components and five language-dependent rule booklets._T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;Japan during the Sengoku or _T_E_M_P_T_A_G_amp;ldquo;Warring States_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_amp;rdquo; Period: each player assumes the role of a great Daimyo with all his troops. Each Daimyo has the same 10 possible actions to develop his kingdom and secure points. To do so he must deploy his armies with great skill. Each round, the players decide which of the actions are to be played out and in which of their provinces. If battle ensues between opposing armies, the unique Cubetower plays the leading role. The troops from both sides are thrown in together and the cubes that fall out at the bottom show who has won immediately. Owning provinces, temples, theaters, and castles means points when scores are tallied. Whichever Daimyo has the highest number of points after the second tally becomes _T_E_M_P_T_A_G_amp;ndash; SHOGUN!_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;Re-implements:_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt; Wallenstein (first edition)_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;

Shogun is based on the Wallenstein game system. The game is set in the Sengoku period (approx 1467-1573) which ends with the inception of the well-known Tokugawa Shogunate. The game is an international edition with language-independent components and five language-dependent rule booklets. Japan during the Sengoku or “Warring States” Period: each player assumes the role of a great Daimyo with all his troops. Each Daimyo has the same 10 possible actions to develop his kingdom and secure points. To do so he must deploy his armies with great skill. Each round, the players decide which of the actions are to be played out and in which of their provinces. If battle ensues between opposing armies, the unique Cubetower plays the leading role. The troops from both sides are thrown in together and the cubes that fall out at the bottom show who has won immediately. Owning provinces, temples, theaters and castles means points when scores are tallied. Whichever Daimyo has the highest number of points after the second tally becomes – SHOGUN! Factory Sealed NEW in Box. Shipping inside the United States is $12.00. Please Email us for shipping rates out of the US. We Will Combine shipping rates for multiple items.

Shipping to a physical address in the US Mainland is $12. Shipping to AK, HI, PR, other US Territories, PO boxes, and APO boxes may be more. International shipping will be more. Please email us for a shipping quote. Shogun is based on the Wallenstein game system. The game is set in the Sengoku period (approx 1467-1573) which ends with the inception of the well-known Tokugawa Shogunate. The game is an international edition with language-independent components and five language-dependent rule booklets. Japan during the Sengoku or “Warring States” Period: each player assumes the role of a great Daimyo with all his troops. Each Daimyo has the same 10 possible actions to develop his kingdom and secure points. To do so he must deploy his armies with great skill. Each round, the players decide which of the actions are to be played out and in which of their provinces. If battle ensues between opposing armies, the unique Cubetower plays the leading role. The troops from both sides are thrown in together and the cubes that fall out at the bottom show who has won immediately. Owning provinces, temples, theaters, and castles means points when scores are tallied. Whichever Daimyo has the highest number of points after the second tally becomes – SHOGUN!

Queen Games (QNG60451F) Japan during the Sengoku or _T_E_M_P_T_A_G_quot;Warring States_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_quot; Period: each player assumes the role of a great Daimyo with all his troops. Each Daimyo has the same 10 possible actions to develop his kingdom and secure points. To do so he must deploy his armies with great skill. Each round, the players decide which of the actions are to be played out and in which of their provinces. If battle ensues between opposing armies, the unique Cubetower plays the leading role. The troops from both sides are thrown in together and the cubes that fall out at the bottom show who has won immediately. Owning provinces, temples, theaters, and castles means points when scores are tallied. Whichever Daimyo has the highest number of points after the second tally becomes - SHOGUN!

This particular copy for sale is the Queen Games_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039; First Edition of Shogun from 2006. It is a multilingual printing of the game. However, only the English rules and player aids are present at the moment. The other languages rules and sheets are somewhere else at the moment. I can look for them if they are needed. This copy has been played at most once. Perhaps half a game. It_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;s been a while. All components (wooden pieces, chits, cards, battle tower, and boards) have been accounted for. The plastic part of the battle tower is clear plastic. The rules and player aids shifted during transport and were heavily bent. For the player aid, it bent near the top of the sheet. The rules were bent along the side. They are very much usable and otherwise in good shape. I got replacements of each from Queen. They are better, but sill not perfect! The plastic insert is in good shape, but you can see cracks starting to form around the edges. This game has been around for quite a while. There are slight indentations on the game box and game board. On the game board, there is a slight indentation on the Sun side in the provinces of Shimotsuke and Hitachi. The box bottom has slight indentations here and there (this game box was usually on the bottom of a large stack of games). The box top is in almost perfect shape with one corner having a bit of dust or something on it (and not coming off). This game comes from a non-smoking home.
